passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: Heraclitus of Ephesus, who lived in the time of Darius, was a man of arrogant disposition and haughty pride

evidence_items.rationale: Direct attribution by Hippolytus with biographical details confirmed by other sources

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: He wrote a book concerning nature which he deposited in the temple of Artemis, but which, according to some, he purposely wrote in an obscure style

evidence_items.rationale: Consistent with external testimony about Heraclitus' intentional obscurity

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: For he desired that his work should be comprehensible only to the able, and not be easily understood by the common people

evidence_items.rationale: Reasonable inference from 'obscure style' comment, consistent with elitist philosophical tradition

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: He maintains that its fundamental substance is fire, which is intelligent and the cause of the government of all things

evidence_items.rationale: Accurate philosophical paraphrase with direct attribution, matches other Heraclitean testimonia

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: For fire, he says, is the most incorruptible of the elements, and all things are exchanged for fire and fire for all things, just as goods are exchanged for gold and gold for goods

evidence_items.rationale: Preserves famous gold exchange analogy, independently attested

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: This fire is kindled and quenched according to measure, and all things happen according to the Logos

evidence_items.rationale: Core Heraclitean doctrine preserved with precise formulation

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: The Logos is eternal, yet men are unable to understand it both before they hear it and when they first hear it

evidence_items.rationale: Matches famous fragment about Logos being universal but unrecognized

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: Heraclitus says that opposites are united, and that from the dissonant there is harmony

evidence_items.rationale: Accurate summary of coincidentia oppositorum doctrine

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: For the way up and the way down are one and the same
God is day night, winter summer, war peace, satiety hunger
He changes like fire which when mixed with spices is named according to the fragrance of each
It is not possible to step twice into the same river according to Heraclitus, nor to touch mortal substance twice in the same state

evidence_items.rationale: Most famous Heraclitean fragment, multiple independent attestations

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: For by the speed of change it scatters and again gathers, comes and goes

evidence_items.rationale: Explanation of river fragment, consistent with flux doctrine

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: For souls to become water is death, and for water to become earth; but from earth comes water, and from water comes soul
The wise man is one thing: to know the intelligence by which all things are steered through all things

evidence_items.rationale: Core Heraclitean wisdom concept, precisely formulated

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: Most men do not think of things in the way they encounter them, nor do they recognize what they experience, but believe their own opinions

evidence_items.rationale: Critique of conventional understanding, consistent with Logos doctrine

passage_mapping.reconstruction_text: This universe, which is the same for all, was not made by any god or man, but was, is, and ever will be an ever-living fire, kindling and being quenched according to measure

evidence_items.rationale: Comprehensive cosmological statement, preserves eternal fire doctrine
